response.message: I got a real feel for how easy electricity has made our modern life while exercising on an exercise bike I made out of an electric generator and an old bicycle. I generate 120 watts for 15 minutes and get just as winded as in a two mile jog. I imagined having to do a two mile jog every time I ran a 120 watt appliance for 15 min or a 60 watt appliance for 30 minutes. That is how easy electricity has made our lives. The energy comes from oil, coal, gas, or nuclear sources but electricity lets us use that energy in so many ways.

response.message:
Sir Lowreys Pas.

Menere. Die oplossing van die geweldige opeenhoping van verkeer na 'n lang naweek is eenvoudig.
Waar die dubbelpad in 'n een baan (af) verander is natuurlik die probleem. Daardie tyd van 'n Maandag is al die swaar voertuie baie min op die pad waar die dubbelbaan (op) 'n redelike groot vereiste is. Die opkomende binne laan kan baie maklik afgeblok word met "cones" tot by die robot waar dit weer 'n dubbel baan is. Ek het met twee beamtes gister gesels en hulle stem heelhartig saam met my dat hulle moet maar dit net gade slaan en daar is niks wat hulle daaromtrent kan doen nie. Skynbaar is die voorstel alreeds met vorige vergaderings deur die beamptes gemaak, maar bestuur stem nie saam met hierdie baie eenvoudige oefeningkie nie. Besoek gerus die area en sien self hoe hierdie geweldige vermorsing van frustrasie, petrol, remme en tyd bespaar kan word. Ek hoop van harte dat my en ander se voorstel met die volgende geleentheid iets van die verlede sal wees.
Groetnis
André Esterhuizen
021 8591015

response.message: Having been a 3 term councillor until 2011 there were questions Asked that to my mind were not either adequately responded to or not at all respoded to. These questions are dated but let me endevour to ask again. Finance depts. Have people dealing with collecting arears, queries etc. The officials or clerks are not trained to make decisions why not? They should know under what conditions credits should be granted or cut offs instituted. A very close scrutiny should happen regarding prepaid meters. Who sells, how many machines and programmes there are , is this all reconciled monthly. Is the information recorded on the customers statement so that customers are able to track their usage. I have never seen a report that can as far as possible accurately say exactly how many mw or kw or ml or kl of electricity and water was charded/ used by a single municipality. Nor was there proper data of kl water losses through leakages or kw due to illegal wire tapping. Surely the above info if available can help govt. And civil society to track progress, get involved and SAVE.

author.name: Nhlanhla kaChanza

response.message: having monitored the work of this Parliament for the past few years I must say that I completely agree with the findings. While our parliament is open its officials at times make it difficult for one to access documents before committees. One has to beg for such documents and this requires the institution to educate committee secretaries in particular about the role they need to play in helping Parliament achieve its vision of being a People's Parliament. The less said about the website the better. It hardly has useful and updated information on hansards, atc's and public representatives. I consult political party websites instead. This has always been the case even with previous parliaments. I will not even touch on the issue of committee minutes. I am not sure why we dont get these, and what officials are for if they cant produce even a one page document that speaks to committee deliberations and decisions made. Having access to committee minutes will go a long away in ensuring that those far from Capetown are able to follow the work of Parliament. Let me keep on dreaming

I am not sure why we dont get these, and what officials are for if they cant produce even a one page document that speaks to committee deliberations and decisions made. Having access to committee minutes will go a long away in ensuring that those far from Capetown are able to follow the work of Parliament. Let me keep on dreaming

response.message:
I paid a visit to the ANC constituency office in Cleary
Park. It clearly states on the door, office closed during 13:00-14:00 for lunch time. I got there at exactly 14:00
and walked in. The lady behind the desk was on the phone, she told the person
to hold on and said very rudely that she was still on lunch. I told her that I
was going according to the sign on the door, she had a attitude, told me
"well I took my lunch at 13:30". She could have firstly, spoken in a
better manner. Secondly, put a sign on the door to say she was on lunch. Her attitude
was pathetic. I went back after 15mins, she helped other people before 14:30
and once again had a pathetic attitude and said she can't help us, we must go
to our ward councillor, I asked her who is that, she said "I don't
know". I thought that these people are there to help assist us, they can't
even deliver a service to the public.
I'm beyond upset and will definitely take this matter further.

response.message:
I am waiting for the coming week to see what parliament decides about Malema's remarks which led to his being banned from the House.

An article in this Sunday's Weekend Argus suggests that the old time culture in the House might be due for a change - continuing with emulating the traditions of the House of Commons, for example, might not be the way to continue to go in South Africa. However, I cannot make any sensible comment on that point! Or maybe - just maybe - I dare not do so!

But if Malema is banned from the House for, say, a month I wouldn't like to forecast what he might get up to in that time - with the spare time on his hands - to cause disruption in the townships. He has seemingly intervened with the miners at Marikana, and one has to wonder whether the continued new demands being made by AMCU - after they came to a preliminary agreement with the mining companies - haven't also been due to interventions by Malema. But that's necessarily speculation.

But Cyril Ramaphosa's recorded comments on SAfm this morning (Sunday) suggesting that the unions don't go overboard with their demands and put businesses bankrupt and having to close down - killing the goose that lays the golden eggs - is something these trade unions need to seriously ponder over. Arguably misleading their members to continue striking whilst the union's officials are happy at home continuing to get their salaries and perks and putting businesses into financial difficulties, could - or should - be considered to be bordering on being a criminal activity. Especially if it ends up with the workers losing their jobs, with no hope of alternate work in the offing.

Many of those workers will have families to support.

response.message: Freedom of religion is great but it cannot be the basis for the law because that would be an infringement upon those who don't have the same beliefs. The law should be based on a compelling government interest and that law is the only way or sufficient to obtain that goal without exchanging society's fundamental right to practice whatever religion they want and not oppress the freedom of religion at the same time.
response.raw_message: Freedom of religion is great but it cannot be the basis for the law because that would be an infringement upon those who don't have the same beliefs. The law should be based on a compelling government interest and that law is the only way or sufficient to obtain that goal without exchanging society's fundamental right to practice whatever religion they want and not oppress the freedom of religion at the same time.

response.message:
The low turnout reflects more on the IEC than on the ZANC. All parties tried to get people to register and to vote (for themselves, of course) but failed to convince the 40%.

Surely it is the IEC's job to persuade citizens how to use their ballots so that, rather than burning things they can fire the government that lets them down.

It is widely believed that the IEC's failure to do so is because it suits the ZANC for the electorate not to think like that and the chair, being a partner of at least one senior ZANC MP, is not prepared to rock this boat.

thread.clean_title: "Why I am spoiling my ballot" :: People's Assembly
thread.title: "Why I am spoiling my ballot" :: People's Assembly

response.message: When I drive around Park lands, table view, Dunoon area I hardly see ANC election posters, I just want to know why it so? Why ANC around this area is so quite, there are no party activities around this area. I also happened to be around the constituency offices and I see a lot of posters locked in there, I wonder who are the leadership there cos at Dunoon you don't see a single ANC poster while they are stacked in the offices. I use to hear about ANC being dead in Western Cape now I see why, with the way this ward doing things I don't see ANC even maintaining the amount of votes it gets in 2009. Whoever is running that office doesn't care about the organisation and it's future in this area. How on earth can parties like IFP, EFF, COPE etc can have their posters everywhere and an organisation like ANC fail to put up a single poster? ANC leaders has come more than twice in Cape Town to canvass votes but this area/branch didn't bother to inform the public. Politics is about numbers and if you are selfish with this organisation people will go where they feel appreciated. My name is Jabulani (0728989856)

response.message: No government official should be in business, nor do business with government. This is simple corruption, as we pay them to work for us. The ANC - Hitachi deal is an insult to all South Africans. It is disgraceful and corrupt. Hitachi and all foreign firms should not encourage corruption by doing deals with politicians. They do not do this in their countries, because they would be jailed. Please forward to ANC and Hitachi.
response.raw_message: No government official should be in business, nor do business with government. This is simple corruption, as we pay them to work for us. The ANC - Hitachi deal is an insult to all South Africans. It is disgraceful and corrupt. Hitachi and all foreign firms should not encourage corruption by doing deals with politicians. They do not do this in their countries, because they would be jailed. Please forward to ANC and Hitachi.

response.message: It's very encouraging to see the number of full service inclusive schools they report. I wonder if that is really the case. sceptical. Government reports on having numbers of sexual offences courts, yet these courts operate exactly as ordinary courts and some (pietermaritzburg for example) stand empty and unused.

response.message: This was a good speech but once again JZ didn't speak about the change he has made during his term of presidency ,he spoke about Nelson Mandela , Oliver Tambo and many more who has done excellent work which I really appreciate but that is history we want to see things happening for the future which will benefit every South African citizen.We want to see economic and social change which will make the lives of South Africans better and indeed things are much better than before 1994

response.message: In my view, this Bill should be scrapped as some of its provisions are in conflict with the constitution. South Africa is a constitutional democracy with one judicial system. This bill envisages the creation of a parallel structure and would be an administrative burden to manage,
